content.title: Terminology

content.content: This menu is still under construction. If you have questions that are not answered here, please ask me.

content.question: How are new keys generated?
content.answer: Keys are generated by taking the FNV32 hash of a completely random UUID. The UUID is generated by the uuid npm package, and should produce unique identifiers for everyone.

content.question: How do I merge string tables?
content.answer: There is currently no standalone STBL merger tool. For now, you can either upload the STBLs you want to merge into a single project and download it, or you can create a project for one of the string tables and import the other one(s) into it. Alternatively, you can still use the existing STBL merger, but keep in mind that that one does not support multiple locales at a time.

content.question: Where is my data stored?
content.answer: All of your data is stored in your browser - it is not in the cloud or backed up in any way. Because of this, I highly recommended regularly backing up your entire workspace by downloading it with the button on the home page.

content.question: Why was my translation erased?
content.answer: To optimize storage, STBL Studio does not store redundant translations. If another locale uses the exact same text as the primary locale, then it is stored as an empty string. When downloading that locale, empty strings will be populated with data from the primary locale.

content.question: What is JSON?
content.answer: JSON is a syntax based off of JavaScript that is used to store data. STBL Studio lets you import/export string tables in JSON format, since JSON is much more user-friendly if you would like to manually add, edit, remove, or reorder entries.

content.question: Expected JSON Structure
content.answer: The JSON format this website uses is very flexible. The top-level structure must be an array that contains objects with two properties, one called "key" (case insensitive) and another called either "value" or "string" (also case insensitive). The value for the "key" property can either be a plain number, or a string containing an 8-digit hex number, with or without the "0x" prefix. This flexible format means that you can paste in the JSON content shown for string tables in S4S, the output of the old STBL editor, or JSON representations of the StringTableResource in @s4tk/models.

content.question: What is CSV?
content.answer: CSV (Comma Separated Values) is a file format that STBL Studio supports as a way to bulk upload strings in multiple locales.

content.question: Expected CSV Syntax
content.answer:
The first row (the header) should contain a comma-separated list of locale names, as defined in the StringTableLocale enum.

All subsequent rows should contain a comma-separated list of strings for each of the locales in the header. If strings contain commas (,), they must be placed within quotes ("). If strings contain quotes, they must be doubled ("").

Tip: If you write your strings in Excel, exporting as a CSV will already account for these comma/quote rules.

content.question: Example
content.answer:
CSV File:
English,Italian
Hi,Ciao
"OK, bye!","OK, ciao!"
"I said ""yes""!","Ho detto ""sì""!"

Parsed As:
EN: 'Hi', IT: 'Ciao'
EN: 'OK, bye!', IT: 'OK, ciao!'
EN: 'I said "yes"!', IT: 'Ho detto "sì"!'

content.question: What are Plain Text Imports?
content.answer: If you have a lot of strings that you haven't hashed yet, you can import them as a plain text (.txt) file, and STBL Studio will automatically create unique hashes for them.

content.question: Expected Structure
content.answer:
Plain text string files are simple – just put every string on its own line. That's it.

There is one catch, though – plain text imports only work with one locale, specifically, the default locale you have in your website settings. To upload plain text strings with multiple locales, use CSV imports.

content.question: All Modals
content.answer: ESC = Close

content.question: Home Page
content.answer:
CMD/CTRL + S = Save Workspace

CMD/CTRL + U = Upload Project

CMD/CTRL + N = New Project

content.question: Home Page (Select Mode)
content.answer:
CMD/CTRL + S = Download

CMD/CTRL + P = Toggle Pin

CMD/CTRL + D = Delete

content.question: Project Page
content.answer:
CMD/CTRL + S = Download

CMD/CTRL + U = Import Strings

CMD/CTRL + N = New String

content.question: Project Page (Select Mode)
content.answer:
CMD/CTRL + H = Rehash Keys

CMD/CTRL + D = Delete Strings

content.question: Project Page (Pagination)
content.answer:
CMD/CTRL + ← = Previous Page

CMD/CTRL + → = Next Page

CMD/CTRL + P = Focus Page Input

content.question: New String
content.answer:
ENTER = Save String

ESC = Cancel String

SHIFT + ENTER = Newline

content.question: Locale
content.answer: A specific language/culture pair that is officially supported by The Sims 4.

content.question: Primary Locale
content.answer: For modders, this is the locale that you plan on writing your strings in. For translators, this is the locale that you are translating from, NOT the one you are writing yourself.

content.question: Project
content.answer: All of the strings associated with a single mod, including their translations.

content.question: Workspace
content.answer: All of your personal data on STBL Studio, including your projects and settings.
